body:
The stage for the next Republican primetime debate will be a little less crowded.
New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee were bumpedÂ from next Tuesdayâs 9 p.m.Â debate to the nightâs earlier debate, Fox Business Network, the debate’s network sponsor, announced, whileÂ former New York Gov. George Pataki and South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham were cut altogether.
To qualify for the Nov. 10 primetime debate, hosted by Fox Business NetworkÂ and The Wall Street Journal, candidates needed an average of 2.5% support in four recent national polls, as determined by the network’s criteria. Mr. Christie earned 2% in a Fox News poll released Wednesday, giving him an average of under the 2.5% threshold.
Messrs. Christie and Huckabeeâs shifting positions mark the first departures from the main stage, aside from candidates who have quit the race. Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul just barely made the cut: He held an average near the 2.5% cutoff in recent polls prior to the Fox News survey, but notched 4% support in Wednesdayâs poll, which helped keep him on the primetime stage. Fox Business said the four polls it counted were the Fox News poll, a recentÂ WSJ/NBC News poll, a Quinnipiac poll, and an Investor’s Business Daily/TIPP poll.
Messrs. Christie and Huckabee still qualify for the earlier debate, which required candidates to garner 1% support in at least one of the four recent national polls. Their departures from the primetime debate leave eight candidates on the main stageâa drop from the 11 who participated in Septemberâs debate.
Earlier Thursday, Mr. Christie appeared to tamp down expectations, saying on Fox Newsâ âAmericaâs Newsroom,â âThe bottom line is you need to be on a stage and debating. I will be on a stage debating one way or the other wherever they put me.â He added on MSNBC that âI donât really careâ about making the cut for the primetime debate.
Both Messrs. Pataki and Graham polled at less than 0.5% in Wednesdayâs Fox news poll. Mr. Pataki had polled at 0% in five previous national polls.
Former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum and Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal also fared poorly in Wednesdayâs poll, each notching less than 1%. But both made the cut for Tuesdayâs earlier debate.
Former Virginia Gov. Jim Gilmore hasn’t qualified for the last two early debates, and failed to make the cut again for next weekâs event.
The primetime debate will be held at 9 p.m. Eastern, and the earlier event at 7 p.m. The debates are taking place in Milwaukee.
Donald Trump will again take center podium in the primetime debate, as the four polls had him remaining ahead ofÂ Ben Carson.
Here are full lineups:
PRIMETIME
Donald Trump
Ben Carson
Marco Rubio
Ted Cruz
Jeb Bush
Carly Fiorina
John Kasich
Rand Paul
EARLY DEBATE
Chris Christie
Mike Huckabee
Bobby Jindal
Rick Santorum

description: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee were bumped from next Tuesday’s Fox Business/WSJ primetime debate to the night’s earlier debate, while former New York Gov. George Pataki and South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham were cut altogether.
title: Christie, Huckabee Miss Cut for GOP Primetime Debate
